com.oracle.tools.runtime.java.process
Interface JavaProcessBuilder

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractJavaProcessBuilder, ExternalProcessBuilder, VirtualProcessBuilder
public interface JavaProcessBuilder

A JavaProcessBuilder is a builder of Java Processes.

This interface is designed to replaced the class-based Java ProcessBuilder implementation. It allows for developers to provide different ProcessBuilder implementations, yet provide a common interface for configuring them.

Copyright (c) 2011. All Rights Reserved. Oracle Corporation.
Oracle is a registered trademark of Oracle Corporation and/or its affiliates.

Author:
Jonathan Knight, Brian Oliver

getEnvironment

Map<String,String> getEnvironment()
Obtains a Map representation of the JavaProcessBuilder operating system environment variables to be used when realize()ing a Java Process.

This Map is initialized to the currently values of the operating system environment variables in which this JavaProcessBuilder is running.

Any modifications to the returned Map will be used for any subsequent Java Process realize()d using this JavaProcessBuilder. However any modifications to the Map won't affect or be reflected in Java Processes previously realize()d with this JavaProcessBuilder.

If the underlying operating system does not support environment variables, an empty map is returned.

Since the external format of environment variable names and values is system-dependent, there may not be a one-to-one mapping between them and Java's Unicode strings. Nevertheless, the map is implemented in such a way that environment variables which are not modified by Java code will have an unmodified native representation in the subprocess.

The returned map and its collection views may not obey the general contract of the Object.equals(java.lang.Object) and Object.hashCode() methods.

The returned map is typically case-sensitive on all platforms.

If a security manager exists, its checkPermission method is called with a RuntimePermission("getenv.*") permission. This may result in a SecurityException being thrown.

Returns:
this JavaProcessBuilder to enable fluent-style method calls
Throws:
SecurityException - when a security manager exists and its checkPermission method doesn't allow access to the process environment
See Also:
Runtime.exec(String[], String[], java.io.File), System.getenv()

getWorkingDirectory

File getWorkingDirectory()
Obtains the JavaProcessBuilder working directory, that of which Java Processes realize()d with the said JavaProcessBuilder will use as their working directory.

Returns:
the working directory of the JavaProcessBuilder. null indicates to use the current Java Process working directory, that of which is typically defined by the system property user.dir

Parameters:
directory - the working directory of the JavaProcessBuilder. null indicates to use the current Java Process working directory, that of which is typically defined by the system property user.dir
Returns:
this JavaProcessBuilder to enable fluent-style method calls

realize

Process realize()
                throws IOException
Realizes a new Java Process using the current attributes of this JavaProcessBuilder.

If there is a security manager, its checkExec method is called with the first component of this object's command array as its argument. This may result in a SecurityException being thrown.

Starting an operating system process is highly system-dependent. Among the many things that can go wrong are:

  • The operating system program file was not found.
  • Access to the program file was denied.
  • The working directory does not exist.

In such cases an exception will be thrown. The exact nature of the exception is system-dependent, but it will always be a subclass of IOException.

Subsequent modifications to this process builder will not affect the returned Process.

Returns:
a new Java Process representing the Java process
Throws:
NullPointerException - when an element of the command list is null
IndexOutOfBoundsException - when the command is an empty list (has size 0)
SecurityException - when a security manager exists and its checkExec method doesn't allow creation of the subprocess
IOException - when an I/O error occurs
See Also:
Runtime.exec(String[], String[], java.io.File), SecurityManager.checkExec(String)
